etymologies: Middle English (as a noun, in the senses ‘strengthening, support, consolation’; as a verb, in the senses ‘strengthen, give support, console’): from Old French confort (noun), conforter (verb), from late Latin confortare ‘strengthen’, from com- (expressing intensive force) + Latin fortis ‘strong’. The sense ‘something producing physical ease’ arose in the mid 17th century

definitions: a state of physical ease and freedom from pain or constraint

examples.text: there is room for four people to travel in comfort

definitions: things that contribute to physical ease and well-being

examples.text: the low upholstered chair was one of the room's few comforts

shortDefinitions: things that contribute to physical ease

definitions: prosperity and the pleasant lifestyle secured by it

examples.text: my father left us enough to live in comfort

definitions: the easing or alleviation of a person's feelings of grief or distress

examples.text: a few words of comfort
they should take comfort that help is available

definitions: a person or thing that helps to alleviate a difficult situation

examples.text: his friendship was a great comfort

definitions: a warm quilt.
ease the grief or distress of

examples.text: the victim was comforted by friends before being taken to hospital

definitions: improve the mood of or restore a sense of physical well-being to

examples.text: he dined outdoors, comforted by the crackling sounds of the fire

definitions: the activity of visiting places of interest in a particular location

examples.text: a sightseeing tour

shortDefinitions: activity of visiting places of interest in particular location

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin sessio(n-), from sess- ‘seated’ (see sessile)

definitions: a meeting of an official body, especially a legislature, council, or court of law, to conduct its business

examples.text: the governor called this week's special session to reconsider the decision

shortDefinitions: meeting of deliberative or judicial body

definitions: a period during which an official body meets regularly to conduct its business

examples.text: legislation to curb wildcat strikes will be introduced during the coming parliamentary session

shortDefinitions: period during which such meetings are regularly held

definitions: the part of a year or of a day during which teaching takes place in a school or college.

definitions: a period devoted to a particular activity

examples.text: gym is followed by a training session

definitions: a period of recording music in a studio, especially by a session musician

examples.text: he did the sessions for a Great Country Hits album

shortDefinitions: period of recording music in studio

definitions: a period of heavy or sustained drinking

examples.text: it was one hell of a session— we must have drunk about 12 cocktails each

shortDefinitions: period of heavy or sustained drinking

definitions: the governing body of a Presbyterian Church.

etymologies: late Middle English: of unknown origin. The word originally denoted a funny story or remark, later an antic or trick, or a frivolous entertainment. The verb dates from the early 16th century

definitions: an object for a child to play with, typically a model or miniature replica of something

examples.text: a toy car

shortDefinitions: object for child to play with

definitions: an object, especially a gadget or machine, regarded as providing amusement for an adult

examples.text: in 1914 the car was still a rich man's toy

definitions: a person treated by another as a source of pleasure or amusement rather than with due seriousness

examples.text: a man needed a friend, an ally, not an idol or a toy

shortDefinitions: person treated by another as source of pleasure or amusement rather than with due seriousness

definitions: denoting a diminutive breed or variety of dog

examples.text: a toy poodle

phrases.text: throw one's toys out of the pram

examples.text: Alan toyed with his glasses

shortDefinitions: move or handle object absent-mindedly or nervously

examples.text: as the courses came and went, she could only toy with her food

etymologies: late Middle English: from French compréhension or Latin comprehensio(n-), from the verb comprehendere ‘seize, comprise’ (see comprehend)

definitions: not successful

examples.text: an unsuccessful attempt to enter Parliament

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French annuel, from late Latin annualis, based on Latin annus ‘year’

examples.text: the sponsored walk became an annual event

definitions: calculated over or covering a period of a year

examples.text: an annual rate of increase

shortDefinitions: living for a year or less

shortDefinitions: book or magazine published once a year

definitions: an annual plant

examples.text: sow annuals in spring

etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘prescribed medical treatment for a disease’): via Latin from Greek methodos ‘pursuit of knowledge’, from meta- (expressing development) + hodos ‘way’

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French tresor, based on Greek thēsauros (see thesaurus)

examples.text: she would always remember the moment they met

examples.text: I was waiting for the right moment to tell him

examples.text: the issues were of little moment to the electorate

definitions: a quantity that expresses the average or expected value of the first, second, third, or fourth power of the deviation of each component of a frequency distribution from a given value, typically mean or zero. The first moment is the mean, the second moment the variance, the third moment the skew, and the fourth moment the kurtosis.

etymologies: Old English fisc (as a noun denoting any animal living exclusively in water), fiscian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vis, vissen and German Fisch, fischen

notes.text: The normal plural of fish is fish (a shoal of fish; he caught two huge fish). The older form fishes is still used, when referring to different kinds of fish (freshwater fishes of the British Isles)

etymologies: Old English lēoht, līht (noun and adjective), līhtan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch licht and German Licht, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek leukos ‘white’ and Latin lux ‘light’

definitions: the natural agent that stimulates sight and makes things visible

examples.text: the light of the sun
the street lamps shed a faint light into the room

notes.text: Visible light is electromagnetic radiation whose wavelength falls within the range to which the human retina responds, i.e. between about 390 nm (violet light) and 740 nm (red). White light consists of a roughly equal mixture of all visible wavelengths, which can be separated to yield the colours of the spectrum, as was first demonstrated conclusively by Newton. In the 20th century it became apparent that light consists of energy quanta called photons which behave partly like waves and partly like particles. The velocity of light in a vacuum is 299,792 km per second

a horizontal moulding, especially a cornice.
a slab of wood or stone bearing an inscription.
shortDefinitions: slab of wood or stone bearing inscription

definitions: a flat surface of a gem.
a cut gem with two flat faces.
shortDefinitions: cut gem with two flat faces

definitions: each half or quarter of a folding board for backgammon.
shortDefinitions: each half or quarter of folding board for backgammon

definitions: present formally for discussion or consideration at a meeting

examples.text: more than 200 amendments to the bill have already been tabled

shortDefinitions: present formally for discussion or consideration at meeting

definitions: postpone consideration of

examples.text: I'd like the issue to be tabled for the next few months

definitions: strengthen (a sail) by making a hem at the edge.
shortDefinitions: strengthen sail by making hem at edge

etymologies: mid 16th century: from Latin anxius (from angere ‘to choke’) + -ous

definitions: feeling or showing worry, nervousness, or unease about something with an uncertain outcome

examples.text: she was extremely anxious about her exams
an anxious look

shortDefinitions: feeling or showing worry, nervousness, or unease about something with uncertain outcome

definitions: (of a situation or period of time) causing or characterized by worry or nervousness

examples.text: there were some anxious moments

shortDefinitions: causing or characterized by worry or nervousness

synonyms.text: with one's heart in one's mouth

definitions: very eager or concerned to do something or for something to happen

examples.text: the company was anxious to avoid any trouble
my parents were anxious that I get an education

shortDefinitions: very eager or concerned to do something or for something to happen

etymologies: early 17th century (in the sense ‘things to be done’): from Latin, neuter plural of agendum, gerundive of agere ‘do’

notes.text: Although agenda is the plural of agendum in Latin, in standard modern English it is normally used as a singular noun with a standard plural form (agendas). See also data and media

definitions: a list of items to be discussed at a formal meeting

examples.text: the question of nuclear weapons had been removed from the agenda

shortDefinitions: list of items to be discussed at formal meeting

definitions: a plan of things to be done or problems to be addressed

examples.text: he vowed to put jobs at the top of his agenda
the government had its own agenda

shortDefinitions: plan of things to be done or problems to be addressed

definitions: the underlying intentions or motives of a particular person or group

examples.text: Miller has his own agenda and it has nothing to do with football

shortDefinitions: underlying intentions or motives of particular person or group

definitions: an appointment diary.

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French policie ‘civil administration’, via Latin from Greek politeia ‘citizenship’, from politēs ‘citizen’, from polis ‘city’

definitions: a course or principle of action adopted or proposed by an organization or individual

examples.text: the government's controversial economic policies
it is not company policy to dispense with our older workers

shortDefinitions: course or principle of action adopted or proposed by organization

definitions: prudent or expedient conduct or action

examples.text: a course of policy and wisdom

shortDefinitions: prudent or expedient conduct or action

etymologies: mid 16th century: from French police ‘bill of lading, contract of insurance’, from Provençal poliss(i)a, probably from medieval Latin apodissa, apodixa, based on Greek apodeixis ‘evidence, proof’, from apodeiknunai ‘demonstrate, show’

definitions: a contract of insurance

examples.text: they took out a joint policy

definitions: an illegal lottery or numbers game

examples.text: he swore that he had never played policy in his life

etymologies: mid 19th century: apparently from a local language of Nepal

definitions: a large bearlike mammal with characteristic black and white markings, native to certain mountain forests in China. It feeds almost entirely on bamboo and has become increasingly rare.

notes.text: Ailuropoda melanoleuca; it is now usually placed with the bears (family Ursidae), but was formerly thought to belong with the raccoons (family Procyonidae)

shortDefinitions: large bearlike mammal with characteristic black and white markings

etymologies: via Hindi from Sanskrit paṇḍita ‘learned, wise’

definitions: a Brahmin expert in genealogy, who provides religious guidance and acts as a family priest.
shortDefinitions: Brahmin expert in genealogy, who provides religious guidance
